Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I gained a new perspective of approaching a problem.
I learned so much about electrostatics, magnetism, and how the two are interconnected.
I learned so much about electricity and magnetism.

I learned about the process of thinking when dealing with nonphysical concepts. It was much harder for me to understand the material than last semester, but Professor Steinacker still did an amazing job.
E&M
I learned about E and M.
I learned a basic understand of electricity and magnetism.
This course was an introduction to electricity and magnetism in physics. In addition to that general topic, it's great practice in terms of analytical skills and problem solving.
Learned comprehensive electromagnetic physics, including electricity, magnetism, basic circuits, etc...
I learned how to solve problems dealing with electricity and magnetism and some fundamental concepts of E&M physics.

My problem solving skills improved a lot from taking this class! Professor Steinacker is great at showing us how how to approach e&m problems and relate it back to real world scenarios. Definitely learned a lot in this class.
Ideas related to charges, electric forces, electric field, electric potential, circuits, capacitors, resistors, current, magnetic field, magnetic forces, and induction.

Aside from learning an array of information about circuits, magnetic fields, and the right hand rule, this course showed me the importance of office hours and asking questions to gain a better understanding of the material.
I learned how to do basic physics, and how to deal with learning difficult concepts.
Learned how to solve complicated problems dealing with electromagnetism, forces, and fields.
I learned about induction, which I found very fascinating
I went into this course having never taken physics in high school so I gained an insane amount of knowledge in this field.

I did not know anything about electricity and magnetism. I would now say I have a great understanding of a lot of concepts within these subjects. The course also helps reinforce the concepts learned in 180. I thought this class covered a remarkable amount of information; this is by far the course I learned the most in.
With this course, I felt my confidence in calculus/physics increase dramatically. Learning about electricity and magnetism was a lot more interesing than mechanics in my opinion.
Electricity and magnetism, a continuation of Physics 180
Lots of experience in solving problems related to a wide variety of physics topics.

I learned what you would expect in an E&M course - electromagnetic fields, conductors, circuits. My calculus and trig skills definitely are much sharper as a result of this and mechanics last semester.
A good understanding of physics focused on electricity and magnetism
I learned a lot about electricity and magnetism, topics of which I knew very little about prior to this course. I feel like I gained a very solid foundation in this field by the end of the year.
Broad exposure to Electricity and Magnetism.
I developed a thorough knowledge of charge, electric fields, forces, as well as magnetic fields and forces. Additionally, I developed a deep understanding of circuits.
This was exactly as the course description. This is an introduction to physics course that goes over basics in mechanics and E&M.
Concepts of physics dealing with electricity and magnetism
Understanding of electricity and magnetism! And overall critical thinking, problem solving skills, and a new appreciation for the way the world works.

I learned themes in electromagnetic physics. This included electric forces, electric fields, electric potential, circuit and themes in magnetism. I also gained insight about how to use math to model physical occurrences.

In this course, I learned about electricity and magnetism, and all of the components included in those subjects. I learned about flux, currents, resistors, capacitors, inductance, and all of the parallel ideas in magnetism. I also learned a lot of mathematics and mathematic manipulation skills necessary to complete the course that are very useful.
The class covered electricity and magnetism. Focuses heavily o the math and problem solving behind these phenomena

I left this course with a deeper understanding of electrostatics and magnetism. While I had taken AP Physics C in high school, the class was challenging enough to be engaging. The course was detailed enough to go over proofs of general physics concepts but the workload remained manageable.
I learned E&M physics.
Insight into a higher level of physics, namely electronics and magnetism.
I learned a lot about circuits as well as other topics relating to electricity and magnetism
I learned about electricity and magnetism.

I gained an extensive overview of physics as it relates to electricity and magnetism, as well as mathematical and problem solving skills and work ethic which I know will prove very useful to me in future courses and endeavors outside the realm of physics itself.
I learned about electromagnetism and critical thinking
I learned about physics specifically circuits and magnetism.
The basics of electromagnetism physics

When you're done with this class, you will actually understand E&M. It's not like AP Physics C where everyone was completely confused but knew a couple equations--you'll understand the concepts and the applications of those concepts. You'll understand why things are the way they are, and you'll be mindblown.
I gained knowledge of magnetism and electricity and I learned how to apply certain tactics to a wide variety of situations.
I learned a lot about electric and magnetic physics!
Learning advanced physics skills.
Knowing how to handle electricity and magnetism well.
How magnetic and electric fields interact, and how those interactions are use to build more.complex systems.
I learned about circuits, electricity, capacitors, magnetism, turbines, and how electricity and magnetism are related to one another.
I learned a lot about electricity and magnetism, including some real world applications.
A lot of problem solving skills! And stamina.
Electricity and Magnetism with calculus

Taking this class I learned a lot about electricity and magnetism. I learned a lot about the very principles of electricity and magnetism, which is useful in a day-to-day context to understand the small things that happens like currents and why magnets work. I also learned how to think outside of the box for this class because the answer wasn't always straight forward. It often took a lot of different approaches to answer the complex questions proposed, which was great for fostering new thinking styles.

I really internalized the logic of understanding physical phenomena in a more quantitative way, and how to use the tools of calculus to understand these systems. My math and physics skills definitely improved, and I've gotten much better at breaking down a problem into more approachable parts.
This course focused a lot on circuits. I learned how problem-solving skills from the PSETS and mastered the right-hand rule!
I learned a lot about electromagnetism!

I learned about electricity and magnetism using essentially only single-variable calculus. I also got to build on a lot of the insights that I learned from last semester, especially simple harmonic oscillation.
This course was able to provide me with the basic knowledge I would need for pursuing an engineering major.
This semester of physics focused on E&M: we learned about electric forces and fields, electric flux, circuits and circuit components, magnetic forces and fields, and magnetic flux/induced current.

I learned the value of office hours through this course. Without Adriane and her office hours, I don't think I would've succeeded in the same way that I did. I gained a lot of knowledge about electric and magnetic fields.
An understanding of charges and electromagnetism as they relate to energy

I learned a lot of new physics topics that will contribute to my knowledge in electrical engineering. We covered topics such as circuits and magnetism and they can relate to each other through electrical current.
much knowledge about electricity and magnetism in physics
This class covers introductory E&M quite thoroughly but stops short of Maxwell's equations.

This course gave me the fundamentals of electromagnetism, including electric circuits, flux, and magnetism - and their applications in everyday appliances and phenomena. I learned to solve conceptual problems more systematically and rigorously, and understand the origins of the formulas used. I became a more critical thinker and problem solver.
Physics knowledge. How to study/prepare.
Problem solving skills and critical reasoning, firm understanding of electrostatics, electric fields, magnetic fields, induction, LRC circuits, etc.
I understood the concepts of electromagnetism much better than before, and felt comfortable using calculus to investigate a wide range of physical phenomena.
This course allows you to develop skills to approach new scientific problems with new ideas. The problem sets stretch the ideas quite far beyond the course.

Strengths- well taught

Weaknesses- unnecessarily complicated and in-depth for an intro physics class. Psets take too long

I don't think that it's necessarily a weakness of the course itself, but the general layout of intro physics here: Physics 180/181 has to try to cater to far too broad an audience, ranging from those with 2 years+ experience with the subject in high school and knowledge of multi-variable calculus (which admittedly matters more in 181 for E&M than in 180 for mechanics) to those with literally no experience in either physics or multivariable calculus. This isn't to say that someone with no experience whatsoever in either of physics or multi can't succeed in 180/181, but as someone in that boat, it's been a lot more rough for me than a lot of my peers and I wouldn't exactly say I've succeeded in the ways they have with this course. Basically, I think there should be perhaps another introductory physics sequence that doesn't force Prof. Steinacker to have to cater to all of these too-varied levels of experience at once.

Strengths: high level of engagement, very interesting classes

Weaknesses: ridiculously long problem sets, lectures where if you doze off for 10 seconds, you're lost for the rest of the class.

Strengths: Professor Steinacker is amazing. She is so dedicated to helping everyone learn: she holds office hours every day so that we can work on the pset and ask questions. She also posts really comprehensive lecture notes so that you can go back and review the material on your own, and her review sessions for exams are super useful for gauging what she will test you on.
Weakness: Not really any. I think sometimes the concepts themselves were confusing, so if I didn't keep up, then class would be a bit confusing.

I loved how Adriane holds multiple office hours and study halls so you can definitely get help. She is such a nice person who really wants you to do well and I like how she learned my name this semester. I thought the psets each week were ok, but the last one was unnecessarily long. The lectures after midterm 2 were pretty confusing and I don't think they were delivered in the best way. Other than that, the lectures were great and conducive to learning.

Strengths: Amazing professor, challenging and engaging PSETS, fair exams

Weaknesses: I felt that study halls this semester lacked the support that it had last semester. Other than that, none.
Lecture notes are great. Problem sets seem pretty (very) tedious and time-consuming. I also feel like I'm lacking in practical electronics knowledge but know a lot of super semantic stuff.
The ending part of the course is way harder than the beginning.  I still do not understand circuits other than very simple ones.
The problem sets take, on average, about 10 hours per week so be prepared. However, the course itself is rewarding and Adriane is a great lecturer, one of the best ones I've had at Yale.

Professor Steinacker is a phenomenal lecturer. She defies many stereotypes of STEM professors and works hard to make the course manageable to students. The TFs and peer tutors are generally very helpful as well.
This course caused me more stress and anxiety than any other course

Strengths: well organized, covers a ton of material, lots of support offered

Weaknesses: people who took AP physics have a huge leg up. Otherwise you're left struggling through conceptually difficult material with little background knowledge. You can get extra help but it often is just too much to learn if you have a weak physics background.

This course was extremely well taught and the professor's lectures were for the most part straightforward and easy to follow. The professor also posts class notes, which make it easy to go back and better understand concepts that might have passed over your head in lecture. Overall, the course is extremely well organized and makes learning easy.
Strengths: learned problem solving skills, mostly interesting topics, interesting lectures. Weaknesses: psets felt long at times, exams were a bit overwhelming content wise

It is a course that dives deep into introductory concepts of electricity and magnetism that challenges students through problem sets and draws connections to various other sciences and concepts in physics. Sometimes, the lectures could get a little dry when the same concept was repeated over and over in various examples. However, I understand that this may be necessary to cater to a wide range of speeds in the class. However, given the amount of extra help available, perhaps the class could be more engaging a little faster/varied.

Strength: Professor Steinacker is a wonderful professor.
Weakness: Problem sets take an awful amount of time.

Strengths - the professor is willing to help with just about anything
Weaknesses - the class is really hard.  This was by FAR my most time-consuming class, and at times your grade doesn't reflect the effort you put in.

The course is well organized and challenging, which is a good thing. The lectures are clear and the feedback, always helpful. I wish the class was a little easier, given how discouraging it can be at times.
The class is well taught by Professor Steinacker. The problem sets were definitely challenging and I would go to office hours almost everyday. However, I did learn a lot.
The PSETs took me a ridiculous amount of time, but I do appreciate how Prof. Steinacker challenged us with the problems. It is just incredibly time consuming so you need to be ready for that.

The biggest strength is the professor. Steinacker is an absolute gemThe class was also extremely informative and I learned a ton. The drawbacks are the workload, and how the psets practically require you to go to office hours to finish.

Professor Steinacker made her herself extremely available for help, and she is empathetic of students' schedules. She made the whole course a great experience. 
My only complaint would be that take-home tests should not be done. It was clear from the high average on the second midterm that there was academic dishonesty and that is frustrating for people who actually strive to be honest.
The lectures were very well taught and the course was structured so students could receive as much help as they needed outside of class.
Great course, very high workload but the instructor more than makes up for it by being absolutely awesome.

The TA, peer tutors, and Steinacker herself are outstanding; dedicating hours to helping us understand the tangle of the question and how to unknot it, until you become almost unconsciously familiar with the logic, the steps to solve. The class notes are clarifying, or crystallizing, with anecdotes (appearing in class also) to engage your interest and contextualize the concepts. 

It may not be a weakness but the length of the psets can be draining; perhaps it is necessary to drudge through them in order to obtain that hard-earned, intuitive understanding; whether or not you had to pester PTs/TAs/Steinacker to guide you along the way or not. 

Some of the homework questions seemed to be unnecessarily convoluted to illuminate the E&M concepts they address, with lengthy algebra-intensive solutions. This, however, is relatively minor and perhaps helps to illustrate the sorts of skills physicists must apply to their own theoretical work.

The psets were so long that it was hard to spend any time actually studying the material. The class itself was really well taught though. Professor Steinacker had really good notes for each lecture, which helped me to fill gaps where I had missed things in her original teaching.

This course is truly designed to allow students to be challenged and to learn a lot over the course of the year. There are many resources for people who are struggling which make the course more accessible. The main weakness in my eyes was the workload. While I expected a heavy load, I spent every single evening throughout the entire semester working on nothing but physics. While I loved the challenge and the rigor, at times I felt frustrated because I spent most of my time working on physics and got a lot less out of my other classes because I couldn't spend as much time working on them as I wanted to.

Strengths: Phenomenal and copious lecture notes posted online, thorough application of knowledge through homework;
weaknesses:  lectures often difficult to sit through, though many were broken up well with short videos or demonstrations.
It's taught very well and there are always TAs available to help you if needed.

Strengths: the weekly problem sets, although long and often times difficult really help you assess what you know and don't know. Additionally, the peer tutors at office hours were amazing and incredibly helpful.

Strengths: The online notes that are posted are very helpful. 

Weaknesses: I find the professors teaching style hard to learn from in class. Tends to over-complicate things rather than try to build a confident foundation for us that we can build upon with further exploration outside of class via her notes.

The most conceptually difficult topics of the class were all at the very end. This made it super hard to learn them because most kids have a million other things to do at that time of the year. This led to a frustrating final that didn't represent our engagement over the first 5/6ths of the course.

The problem sets were extremely laborious. While I don't believe they are as difficult as people say (taking 10+ hours a week), I was annoyed by how math heavy they were. The ugly integrals and derivatives were prone to mistakes, and most of my time was often spent getting the answer in the right form or looking for small math errors as opposed to understanding the physics. The strength of this course is Steinacker. She is an incredibly kind hearted professor who really wants to help her students in any way possible. While I felt like she treated students she favored better, she was incredibly kind across the board.

This was amazing course! It really depends on you whether you like and do well and put in the work. The professor was amazing and the course material interesting. I did not do that well just because I am still figuring out how to study (I suggest writing down steps for each type of problem and then doing practice problems).
Great professor, long and hard problem sets, but also plenty of opportunities to seek and obtain help

This course was well structured overall. Steinacker cares for her students sooo much it's unbelievable, and her passion inspires the students to truly learn the material and gain confidence in physics. Her dedication extends far beyond the classroom, and she always makes herself available in office hours and other contexts to help us learn.

There was a strong community of students that helped to increase support in the class. The professor and peer tutors were very helpful in office hours. The professor was willing to answer questions and asked on the status of the class's understanding during session.

The course covers a lot of material and uses a lot of calculus in the material so I think that possibly taking multivariable calculus before the course would be beneficial. The course itself teaches a lot of the fundamentals of physics and is a great introduction to the world of physics.

Adriane steinacker is a gem and what makes this course bearable. In order to cover the necessary material, the class assumes a certain prior knowledge which can make it tough to keep up with if you have a weaker background. Psets are extremely time consuming and can pretty much only be done in office hours or study hall since for most they are too hard to do alone, but they do prepare you well for the exams

The lectures I believe could focus a bit more on the concepts behind these phenomena so they are more interesting, instead of focusing on deriving the formulas given on the formula sheet. Still, the P-sets are fantastic and facilitating student learning, as they encourage collaboration and teach concepts through actual problems.

The course has very complected problem sets but the study halls available and class notes were very useful resources. The lectures were a great improvement from 180, much more  concise and easier to follow.

Strength: Steinacker, enough said
Weakness: The p-sets take a while if you are a normal person
The strengths of the course are that Professor Steinacker is great and that the structure is manageable. The weakness is that the lectures are a little dry and hard to follow.
The teacher was amazing and I thought it was well paced but difficult. Honestly I dont have a ton of ways to make it better, but maybe more office hours.
Very well structured, basic tools we learned in previous lectures were applied again with a deeper understanding of their purpose.
Sometimes I felt that we covered material very quickly which made it difficult to full understand all the concepts

This is an amazing course with no weaknesses. The professor is amazing, and the problem sets help facilitate learning a lot. Lecture is very helpful for learning the material as well, and the consistent help sessions are very beneficial.
The psets are too difficult, but professor steinacker is an amazing lecturer.

The strengths of the course are Professor Steinacker's passion for the material and her students and the availability of help. In such a large lecture, students come into the course with highly variable background knowledges of physics and mathematics, so it may be difficult for some students to keep up or learn the material based on lectures alone. However, there are notes posted on Canvas which are very detailed and extremely useful in terms of explaining the material covered in class in greater detail or in a different way which allows students to better understand it. These notes are also very helpful when it comes time to go back and review materials that were covered earlier in the semester, as they are more organized and detailed than a typical student's class notes and can be used to fill in gaps in understanding. Other strengths include the fact that office hours and study hall sessions are held so frequently, that there are so many peer tutors and TAs available to provide help, that there are weekly review sessions, that there are lengthy review sessions before each exam, and that test corrections are allowed. Last semester I found the exams to be unreasonably difficult, giving me massive amounts of stress and anxiety leading up to them, but I generally found the exams in 181 to be, though still of course challenging (as they should be), much more fair. The biggest weakness, I would say, is the massive number of hours that must be spent on problem sets per week. I understand that it is necessary to have difficult problem sets for a course like this, but perhaps they could be cut back slightly in length. The massive number of hours that I needed to spend per week working on problem sets cut into my focus for other classes and time that I would've liked to spend doing research work.
It is taught very well
Steinacker is a fantastic Professor but the class is super hard.

I like how she bases her grades off of how much effort she puts in, but she doesnt know who goes to study hall so maybe she should have people sign in if they go to study hall if she really wants to help improve your grade if you show that you put in a lot of work. Because I could never get to her office hours due to class and other required events.

This course is really hard, which could be considered a weakness, but really it's a strength. The homeworks help you really get the concepts into your head and pretty much require a bit of teamwork, so you'll hear other people explain things or you'll explain things to people and reinforce everything. Prof. Steinacker is one of the greatest lecturers ever--she explain it well, she's funny, engaging, and VERY caring about the students and the topics. She is the greatest strength of this class.

I learned a lot in this course and I feel like I became more able to handle what I was given as the course proceeded. The difficulty of the problem sets is inconsistent week to week which sometimes makes it difficult to prepare properly.
Problem sets were tough but great preparation for the exams
A lot of work, but its rewarding because it pays off. So a weakness is how time consuming it is, but a strength is the level of comprehension that comes with it.
Her office hours were very useful. I did not notice any major weaknesses

Strengths: the support that the professor offers by having many office hours, the topics, the enthusiasm of the professor while teaching, the style of teaching, and providing the lecture notes to the students. 
Weaknesses: none

It is ridiculous that going into the final I had 5 weeks of homeworks (and my last exam) that were ungraded. The TAs for physics have been the least prompt TAs of any class I've taken at Yale. Learning occurs when the feedback is fast, something which the TAs failed to do both semesters. I have taken classes where TAs have a turn around time of a few days. Over a month is nowhere close to acceptable.

Strengths: So many office hours/study halls, a grading system that emphasizes the homework, and homework that (although it's very difficult) really forces you to learn and retain the material if you devote time to it.  The course is organized for students success, and allows you to get back what you put in.  You won't have hours of busy work that don't actually enhance your knowledge of the material.

Weakness: This isn't so much a weakness, but it is a very challenging class.  I think especially towards the end of the semester when there were more psets due on Sunday (as opposed to Friday), it would've been nice to have even more office hours because otherwise the students who are behind just mooch off of the students who went to office hours early in the week. There was a TA who did a review of concepts, but it was on Monday evenings.  Personally, I didn't have that time free, but I also wonder if a time towards the end of the week would've been better.  Having class on Monday and Wednesday means between Wednesday and the next Monday, there are practically five days of no lecture, so I think the review of materials might be good on a Friday.
Very well taught, but PSETs are very long and require peer-tutor help. Although the support system is sufficient if you use it

There were no real weakness of the course. The main strength of the course was definitely the instructor. Professor Steinacker is an amazing professor and was able to beautifully convey the information whether in class, office hours, or her online notes. The class was very much a success because of her teaching style.

I think having the notes for each lecture available before class would be amazing because it's hard for me to understand everything when seeing it for the first time. If the notes are not made available before class, then it might also be better to skip some of the smaller algebra steps and focus more on the conceptual parts and just note that the algebraic steps are available in the notes.

The class is manageable but the PSETS are long and frustrating if you don't go to office hours. Professor Steinacker does a great job making resources available to help students understand the material! Lectures were long but professor Steinacker is a great lecturer. A weakness of the class is that there is a wide range of experience level with physics and there are many students that have much more experience in physics than others so they should have been in the higher level physics class.

The strengths of this course are that it builds very naturally off of PHYS 180; the problem sets are reasonable; there is lots of help for the problem sets; the exams are easier than the problem sets, which makes them less stressful; the course is extremely well-organized; and that it goes through what are traditionally seen as difficult concepts in physics in a very easy to digest way. The main weakness is that I feel like we could do more. I especially felt this way after the professor showed us how to derive Maxwell's Equations on the last day of class, since these equations have SO much potential in physics. But, I guess people can take PHYS 201 or 261 if they really want more...

The biggest strength is Prof. Steinacker. She is a gem (much like her favorite problems), and her passion for the subject makes her students care about it too. She is very organized in the way she teaches and her online notes are a great guide. The only suggestion I have for improvement is to perhaps slow down a tiny bit during class, especially toward the end of the semester.
A real strength of this course was the alignment of the course content in every aspect: homework, class, exams, etc. It was an immense time commitment.

The biggest strength of this course is professor Steinacker. She is beyond dedicated to helping every student learn the material and do well in the course. The biggest weakness of this course is definitely the homework. Quite simply, I see no point in having homeworks so long and so challenging. Instead of spending countless hours stumbling through tedious algebra, students could learn the material much better if they could instead use that time to study in other, more direct ways. More often than not, when the problem sets got too difficult, many students would simply go to peer-tutoring or study hall, obtain the answers, and leave without really learning the underlying concepts behind the material. In this sense, I really think students should be encouraged to work through the problems on their own first and only later resort to outside help. A better way to facilitate this would be to make the problems sets easier but with more problems. I often felt like many of the concepts we learned in class were not "relevant" just because one of the long homework problems did not address them. Having problem sets with easier but more problems would a.) allow more testing on more content of the course, and b.) encourage students to start the work on their own first.

Steinacker is a wonderful Professor- her office hours and study hall are incredibly helpful and I appreciate that notes are posted online. In class however I find that my notes can seem a bit disorganized. Otherwise, conceptually a very logical progression in material
I felt that is students were given every opportunity to do well and there were not many weaknesses if any.

absolute defining strength of this course is Adriane Steinacker. She is completely extraordinary in her love for students, for teaching, for the material of this coursereally cannot imagine it being done better than her. she dedicates so much extra time to helping her students during office hours, puts so much time into writing thought provoking yet doable problems, and is super fun to interact with.

Strengths 
-Professor Steinacker--A strength that cannot be overstated. She is a gem.
-Extremely frequent office hours
-Very well organized class notes--I think this one is not talked about much but a big one for me
-Exam reviews--Exceptionally good at clarifying key concepts, especially when compared to review sessions for other classes
-Problem Sets--Difficult and a bit time consuming but working through them well really helped you learn the material

Weaknesses
-After the take-home midterm I learned that a lot of students used their notes which was not allowed. Which is sad :(  Not sure if this is a weakness of the course, but in general I don't think take home exams seem suited for this class
-Sometimes it felt like the peer tutors acted more as answer checkers than tutors, which is understandable when the question they usually get is "Did I get this one right?" Still, I think it would have ben nice at times if they were a bit more focused on broader concepts than on the specific answers you got for a given problem

The course is well-structured thanks to Professor Steinackers rigor and organization. Each class has a defined set of topics to cover, and supported with historical context and everyday examples. Each lecture is also in notes form on Canvasback to review concepts. The homework assignments help us understand the material through practice, and Steinackers willingness to help students and doing the problem sets together made the assignments fun and learning bonding experience.
I felt I was very left behind. Some students were just much more prepared/over qualified for the course.

Strengths: teaching was fantastic! Lecture was extremely useful, problem sets were challenging but doable if you pay attention in class, and there were ample opportunities for extra help. Professor Steinacker went far above and beyond to make sure that any student who asked for help received it!

The course is taught very well, and the lectures were some of the most enjoyable and engaging lectures I've had at Yale. The weekly problem sets are not easy or short, but they really help the understanding of the course material, and with the amount of office hours and study hall, they are very doable when one plans their schedule for it. Also, the course really fosters a very supportive community between the students, which is a very important quality I wish more courses at Yale were able to achieve.

This course, like Professor Steinacker's Physics 180 course, is truly one of the most well-run courses at Yale. There is an abundance of help for problem sets between office hours and study halls in which Professor Steinacker and the peer tutors really dedicate themselves to helping their students. One weakness of this is that it often feels like office hours are not a place where you can ask for help for broader conceptual questions or for help preparing for an exam. The lectures are very clear and engaging, and Professor Steinacker's appreciation for physics really shines when she lectures.
The course requires a lot of assistance from TAs and the professor, but you end up learning a lot.

Yes. I think that if you need to take a physics class, then Phys 180/181 is a really great choice. It will definitely be challenging and a lot of work, but if you are willing to put in that effort and time into the class, then you will be fine and Professor Steinacker knows that you are trying really hard. You also learn a lot about electricity and magnetism and even some math, but everything you need to know will be taught in class.
Yes, I would recommend this course. Adriane is an amazing instructor and I really enjoyed learning from her.
Yes, this course will teach you to have a mindset that goes far beyond a college physics course. It will challenge you and help you grow, but you will have to put in some work.
absolutely!
Yes. If you need it for your major or another requirement. Not super thrilling in general so prob only if you need it.
I wouldn't recommend taking this class unless you had to. The content is hard and the problem sets take way too long.

For many students, this is a required class. I think it's still possible to enjoy it by itself, however. The psets definitely take time and can be frustrating, but working through them is ultimately rewarding and great practice in truly understanding the material. I felt lost during a lot of the class, but as I went back through the material to study for the final I was surprised at my level of comfort with everything. Most of this was thanks to investment Professor Steinacker makes in her students' education.

If you love physics, you'll probably like this class. If you don't like physics, you'll probably hate it. Professor Steinacker is super nice, but her teaching style just isn't for everyone. This course is conceptually quite difficult and the math is quite tough at times. If you need to take it it's manageable but the course is not super engaging as its lots of dry calculations. People who took AP physics have a huge leg up. Otherwise you're left struggling through conceptually difficult material with little background knowledge. You can get extra help but it often is just too much to learn if you have a weak physics background. There isn't really another intro option though...
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to gain an introductory level understanding of electricity and magnetism in physics.

I would recommend this course to someone looking to be challenged. You definitely need to put a good amount of time into this class to do well but what you put into it you get out of it! I definitely learned a ton in this class.

I would recommend this class. Professor Steinacker does her best to ensure that every student can succeed, and although the material is challenging and extremely conceptual, it is interesting and rewarding to master.

I would recommend this course only to people interested in physics or fulfilling other major requirements. It is definitely an effective way to learn physics thoroughly, but the workload is high and there is no reason to take this class as a gut or to fulfill distributional requirements.

Yes. Although this course dives into complicated topics that sometimes leads your intuition into a void and requires many dedicated hours of work, the knowledge and feeling of accomplishment upon completing the multitude of problem sets and the course as a whole is worth the while.
Not unless they are interested in physics or engineering; this course is far too difficult to be taken unless it is necessary

Chances are you need to take this course. It will be challenging, but if you go into it with an open mind and a willingness to suffer a lil, it wont be that bad. I promise you will survive and it will be fine
This course is difficult, but if you put the time and work into the course, it will pay off.
Yes! Professor Steinacker is such a great person to get to know.
Yes! Especially if it is taught by Steinacker. She is truly incredible.
Not unless they were actually interested in physics. With the amount of work the class could be considered 2 credits, so it is only for people that want to learn about the material.
YEs, if professor Steinacker teaches it
Yes, Professor Steinacker is a great professor and you will learn a lot.

Yes, do this course if you love physics and want to meet a truly amazing instructor who will help you every step of the way.The course content is boilerplate at heart, but the instructor makes it fun and fresh and if you already like physics you will love it.

I cant speak for how this compares to 171, but if you enjoy math puzzles this might appeal to you. There are definitely weeds you have to wade into  exhausting systems of equations for solving circuits, for instance, or tricky integrals, and some slippery concepts that seems at times untethered from reality (unlike mechanics).

Perhaps that is a consequence of the material itself rather than the course; certainly Steinacker does an exemplary job writing class notes and tirelessly appearing at office hours. 

Certainly I can say, if you intend to take this course (and are not some sort of physics genius), ensure that you have time free to attend study hall or office hours (preferably the latter, which tend to occur at times one might otherwise be in class/work/lab; so might require some planning around). Psets take at least 7 hours of my time, with extensive help; if I were to struggle through alone it would take longer and I would tend to head in the wrong direction, solution-wise. This is not the case for everyone, of course, and I hear that psets have been reduced in length significantly compared to previous years to help rectify this issue.
If its required definitely. Its a bit much work for a person to take this simply for a distribution

Only if your workload is manageable. The class is challenging and interesting but required most of my available time consistently throughout the entire semester. However, you will learn a lot and Professor Steinecker is one of the best professors I've ever had.
Take this course if you're trying to fulfill an engineering requirement.

I would recommend this course to another student because, while the material was very challenging and there was a lot of work for the course, Professor Steinacker taught the material well and her dedication to our learning made it more worthwhile because she would answer questions until we understood what was going on. However, it is a lot of work and pretty challenging in my opinion, so just be aware of that going in.

If Adriane Steinacker is teaching PHYS 181, absolutely!! She is a wonderful gem of a professor - one of the few professors you will meet who genuinely just cares about your learning and tries her very best to facilitate a great learning environment. PHYS 181 is a lot of work but completely worth it if you put in the effort. As long as you put in the work, this course will reward you.
Yes, if it's required. Try to engage or it will be horrible.

I would recommend it over 171 if you have a relatively good math background (115 should suffice). I heard negative comments about 171 through the semester as well, and both classes seemed relatively difficult. I think, however, that it is worth getting to know Steinacker as a professor. Although, if you want to learn as little physics as possible, the other course is better. As much as I like math and problem solving, I was not a fan of the material taught in E&M.
Yes! I would very much recommend this course because of Professor Steinacker! If you are interested in Physics at all, then take this course with this professor.
Yes! If you are interested in physics and don't mind long psets.
I would recommend this course to other students who need this for their major or are looking to improve in physics.

I would recommend this course to another student. Although it was difficult, the material was very interesting and the course structure was pretty standard. I enjoyed the course a lot and was happy with how much I learned.
I would recommend this course as it is taught very well.

Yes. The p-sets will require much of you, but you will have the help you need to complete them in office hours and study hall, and more than this you will get to know Steinacker. She is worth it. Take her class.
Only if it is required.
Yes especially if they are at all interested in physics. It is well taught and very interesting, but difficult and you need to put the time into it.

Yes. Information is presented clearly and directly, ample opportunities are provided for students to get help or ask questions about problem sets. The professor is phenomenal and clearly loves what she is doing.
Yes if you want to learn more physics and are willing to put in the work
I would highly recommend this course to another student if they are interested in physics.
I didn't take multivariable calculus or differential equations, so I struggled with homework problems and didn't feel I could keep up with everyone else.
Yes, if you are looking to learn a detailed overview of physics.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested, but also would warn them to be ready to commit a lot of time and effort if they want to do well.
Definitely
I would recommend this course if its a requirement.
Yes she loves what she teaches and is super nice!
This is a very difficult p set intensive course but you really learn a lot and Steinacker makes it worth it.
yes; there's a range of applications to other fields that the instructor addresses, and it's a very social class in that you make friends in office hours and in class!
Yes, Professor Steinacker is an amazing professor who wants to make everyone better at physics. The class is organized, work is graded fair, and the class content is very interesting
Yes. I think the course teaches work ethic and stimulate certain discipline with problem solving. It is rewarding.
Yes, because it teaches the very fundamentals of electricity and magnetism
Yes, definitely. This is the best physics class I have ever taken and almost convinced me to switch my major to physics.
From what I've heard, the 170 class seems to be better organized, but I cannot entirely speak to that. People take this class because they have to, so I think recommendations are fairly null.

Absolutely.  Out of every intro STEM course I have taken at Yale, this is by far the best.  Many big lectures are not personal, cannot make a student feel known, and often only offer extra help to those whose grades reflect that they are really struggling. Much of my recommendation of this course has to do with Professor Steinacker, but I hope whoever continues teaching this course will carry on her legacy and continue to implement those things that I listed as strengths.  This course is extremely demanding and the psets took me upwards of 10 hours each week, but I liked the routine of going to office hours every afternoon, making friends there (something prof steinacker mentioned at the start of the year, but I didn't really believe could be true) and getting help on the psets.

To me, PHYS181 was easier than PHYS180 simply because I was already familiar with the structure of the class. Once you know how to study and how to get help, it's pretty much a matter of putting in the hours to to the psets and study for exams. Yes, the concepts in 181 are conceptually harder than 180, but I don't think I spent significantly more time doing work for 181 than 180. Definitely go to office hours and read Prof Steinacker's notes before the exams.
Yes, it is very well taught and the instructor is very much invested in teaching. You rigorously learn physics from first principles

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Although it is a good amount of work, you learn a lot of basic principles about electricity and magnetism that helps you better understand them. Although you may not use all of the information, the basics are important for everyone to know.
Yes, take this over any other intro physics unless you have good math preparation.
If you have to take physics, take it with Professor Steinacker!
Take it if you must but dont just take it as a QR unless youre masochistic.

Absolutely! It's super well-organized and you'll have a great foundation for studying electricity and magnetism (E&M) in the future. I came into this class a bit concerned because I had never studied the majority of topics in E&M, but it was actually fairly easy because of how well the course was taught. The professor is spectacular and will work with you whether you're awesome at physics or think you're terrible at it. She really enjoys teaching and made this class great.

I would; Prof. Steinacker is great about making the course challenging but not too crazy difficult, and if you are struggling there are definitely resources in place to help. I was deciding between the Physics 170/1 sequence compared to this one, and I'm glad I chose Prof. Steinacker's sequence. She is truly one of the best professors at Yale and I'm glad I got to experience her passion and contagious joy for one year!
If you need it, or want to learn more about electricity and magnetism.
This is a great course for learning physics, but be prepared to do a lot of work for the problem sets.

YES. This is a fantastic course. Taking it with Prof. Steinacker is so worth it. Would 100% recommend over 170/171, especially if you have a decent foundation in math. I made friends in this course! I learned so much! The psets are definitely a lot of work and took up a lot of my time, but the community is real and valuable. This is what collaborative learning should be like.
I took this class instead of 171 and I was happy with my choice, because of support inside and outside the classroom

for sure! it's a good deal of work, i recommend going to study hall and office hours as much as you can. for some people on some weeks, it only takes 3 hours to finish a pset, for some people on some weeks it can take 15! so don't worry if you feel slow :) everyone in the class is on your side, from Adriane to peer tutors, TAs, and other students. of course it probably varies year to year but i found our cohort to be super supportive and charitable, explaining problems to other students and the like
No.
Yes, definitely take this over the physics 170 sequence.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in STEM - having a solid background in physics, and especially understanding highly relevant concepts in electromagnetism in the digital age is invaluable. The course is a lot of work, and its important to stay on the material and spend time on the problem sets to understand how to solve the problems methodically.
Yes, great introduction to college level physics.

Amazing course! I went into it with very little interest in physics and came out of it wishing that I had the time to take more. Extremely clearly taught and very rewarding if you are willing to put in the effort! Problem sets are very doable, especially if you start early and build the time into your schedule to go to office hours (she offers 10 hours a week!). Super worth taking for the intellectual challenge and to get to know Professor Steinacker - she is incredible and a great person!

I would highly recommend this course to other students who need physics, but ALSO to anyone who wants to understand physics without necessarily having it as a requirement. I took it as a junior, and although I decided against it long ago, this course reminded me why years ago I wanted to choose physics as my field of study.

Physics 181 with Professor Steinacker is a fantastic intro physics course to take. The psets are quite long and difficult, but there is so much help available (office hours, study halls, peer tutors, etc.) that it makes the workload manageable. I feel like I really have a strong grasp of physics after taking this course, and this is thanks to Professor Steinacker's dedication to her students and passion for physics.
Yes, this is a great intro course. The class is well-designed for student success.
